author: By     Byron Tau
title: Obama calls for limits on prison for non-violent drug offenders
text:
Getty Images U.S. President Barack Obama, alongside Charles Samuels (right), Bureau of Prisons Director, and Ronald Warlick (left), a correctional officer, tours a cell block at the El Reno Federal Correctional Institution. President Barack Obama undertook a landmark visit on Thursday to the El Reno Federal Correctional Institution in Oklahoma, to push for a broad reduction in the incarceration of non-violent drug offenders.
In what was described as the first visit by a sitting president to a federal prison, Obama met with six inmates at the medium-security penitentiary and toured the facility with a correctional officer and an official with the federal Bureau of Prisons.
“When they describe their youth, these are young people who made mistakes that aren’t that different from the mistakes I made, and the mistakes that a lot of you guys made,” Obama told reporters about his roundtable meeting with the inmates. “The difference is that they did not have the kind of support structures, the second chances, the resources that would allow them to survive those mistakes.”
All six of the prisoners with whom Obama met were serving time for drug offenses. Speaking briefly after his roundtable and tour of the facility, Obama said that the United States ought to reconsider its policy of punishing drug crimes with decades-long sentences.
